channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jacob Zuma Impeachment Debate Begins in South Africa
item.description: The opposition party motion to impeach Mr. Zuma, which was begun over a long-running corruption case, is given little chance of passage.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa answering lawmakers’ questions in Cape Town last month.

item.title: Zika Forest Journal: In a Remote Ugandan Lab, Encounters With Zika and Mosquitoes Decades Ago
item.description: A forested site where science and exploration overlapped in the discovery of numerous viruses is today a little patch of forest, but research into the Zika virus continues.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: Researchers from the Uganda Virus Research Institute carrying insect traps in Zika Forest.

item.title: Myanmar Approves New Title for Aung San Suu Kyi, Rankling Military
item.description: Some members of Parliament denounced the measure, which could give her authority exceeding the president’s, as an unconstitutional power grab.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nyein Chan Naing
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, the armed forces chief, in Naypyidaw, the capital, last week. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi will become “state counselor” under a measure approved on Tuesday by Parliament’s lower house.

item.title: Despite Several Blows to Shabab, Worries Persist About Their Resilience
item.description: The recent strikes against the militant group in Somalia will “hurt them, no doubt,” an analyst said, “but they tend to regenerate.”
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Shabab fighters during military exercises on the outskirts of Mogadishu, Somalia, in 2011. The Pentagon said last month it had killed 150 militants in an airstrike.

item.title: North Korea Is Able to Mount Nuclear Warhead on Missile, South Says
item.description: An official added that South Korea had no evidence that the North had deployed such nuclear-tipped Rodong missiles, which could reach all of the South and most of Japan.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Sentry posts belonging to North Korea, in the background, and the South on opposite sides of the border.

item.title: Sinosphere: China Censors Mentions of ‘Panama Papers’ Leaks
item.description: The top censored phrases monitored on Weibo all appeared to be related to the leaks: tax evasion, file, leaked, Putin and company.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The leaks showed that Li Xiaolin, the daughter of the former premier Li Peng, and her husband, Liu Zhiyuan, owned a foundation based in Liechtenstein that in turn owned a company in the British Virgin Islands, Cofic Investments.

item.title: Indonesia’s Orangutans Suffer as Fires Rage and Businesses Grow
item.description: The blazes, an annual occurrence where farmers clear land by burning it, often for palm oil plantations, have led to the relocation and even deaths of some of the apes.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Orphaned orangutans at a rehabilitation center in the Indonesian province of Central Kalimantan.

item.title: Sinosphere: Donald Trump, Despite Bashing Beijing, Is Not Without Fans in China
item.description: As Mr. Trump gains ground in the Republican presidential race, the ranks of Chinese cheering him on have swelled.
item.dc:creator: CAO LI
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump has been assailed in the Chinese state media, but the Republican presidential candidate has also attracted some Chinese supporters for his willingness to speak his mind.

item.title: U.N. Strives for Transparency in Picking New Secretary General
item.description: While the United Nations is trying to make the selection of a new secretary general more transparent, the world powers are, as usual, expected to exert undue influence over the process itself.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Panama Law Firm’s Leaked Files Detail Offshore Accounts Tied to World Leaders
item.description: News media outlets said the documents revealed the accounts of 140 politicians, including figures with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: The documents revealed the offshore accounts of 140 politicians and public officials, including several individuals with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Here’s What We Know About the ‘Panama Papers’
item.description: The documents name international politicians, business leaders and celebrities in a web of unseemly financial transactions, according to news articles.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Skyscrapers and residential buildings lining the beach in Miami. A report by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists indicated possible connections between condo purchases in South Florida and money laundering.

item.title: World Briefing: Ivory Coast: Politician Acquired Tons of Weapons, U.N. Investigation Finds
item.description: During the 2011 civil war, Guillaume Soro, the parliament speaker, acquired 300 tons of weapons, many of which remain under the control of his loyalists in the army.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Meeting in Rome on Killing of Italian Student is Postponed
item.description: Egyptian officials have postponed a trip to Rome to discuss the investigation into the killing of Giulio Regeni whose body was found on the outskirts of Cairo in February.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: U.S. Seizes Weapons at Sea
item.description: American Navy ships in the Arabian Sea intercepted and seized an arms shipment from Iran likely bound for Houthi rebels in Yemen, the military said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Conflict Brings Hunger Crisis
item.description: The two-year-old conflict in eastern Ukraine has left about 1.5 million people hungry, including nearly 300,000 in need of immediate help, the World Food Program said.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Letter From Europe: Crippling Strike in France May Have Been About More Than Labor Law
item.description: The walkout appeared to have less to do with proposed changes to labor law than disaffection with President François Hollande’s government.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Workers demonstrating in Marseille, France, on Thursday.

item.title: Ethnic Conflict Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Flares Anew
item.description: A new round of fighting in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region has killed at least 44 people.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Gunfire Ends Post-Election Calm in the Republic of Congo
item.description: An armed group rampaged overnight in Brazzaville, the capital, shattering a relative calm since the re-election of President Denis Sassou-Nguesso.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Global Health: Yellow Fever Outbreak in Angola Strains Health Organizations
item.description: A crisis threatens other countries, including China, and exposes how poorly prepared the world is to fight two mosquito-borne epidemics at once.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Dr. Margaret Chan of the W.H.O.

item.title: ‘Panama Papers’ Leaks Put Iceland Prime Minister Under Pressure to Quit
item.description: Calls for the resignation of the prime minister were among the first repercussions of the leaks on secret tax shelters and offshore shell companies.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
